text:
Huh.

First time as a participant in RunNUS; let's not even get started with being a pacer for 15km.

I think 100 minutes for 15km sounded and felt pretty daunting to me at the start because I stopped training because of spikes in workload and having to deal with the fallout of everything that's happened on my emotions and mind. Not helping that I fell ill a little. Come to think of it, I fall ill the most often in the team, I think?

It's not a daily thing anymore where I feel really low and just don't want to do anything but just break down and give up. But it happened the night before and I was seriously concerned about whether I could clear that 15km, with so many thoughts and emotions to process at once that my mind and emotions began going out of control again. I had difficulty sleeping and overslept by a little as a result. And by a little, I meant by a lot. It still happens.  But I guess I have to keep working at it, yes?

Just wishing there was more helium though. Just saying.

'Why didn't you take part?' 'Didn't feel right to take part, with everything going on, maybe it's better to stay out of this.'

Tough month.

It's going to get a little more slack here on out till November. But yeah. Nearly gave up so many times and everything but I just kept getting up and continued doing what I needed to do.

Asshole robot in Taiwan malfunctioned and burned my Saturday evening. Yeah. But here are some pictures I got from my work experience in Taiwan!

Of course, I've seen better views.

But there's something about these sceneries that make me feel at ease.

I feel a kind of reconnection to something. I intuitively know I can trust that nothing will go wrong in this. Like I feel myself opening up more significantly in this state of mind, as if I am at peace and free, away from the pressures in this world.

Now, this is a view I can get used to.

I don't know, it's like when I look out there at night... I can't help but wonder about the people who work there. About their families and lives outside work. They aren't just bringing food to their families; they're playing a part in putting things on shelves and racks for us to decide what we wish to purchase.

I feel like I've never trusted them. It just doesn't feel right to me, and I think it is on me that I don't trust them. But strangely, I'm not apologetic about it (me, apologetic? That's rare). Is it because I tend to treat people equally, regardless of wherever they come from, whatever they've done, whoever they are? There are people telling me about how the labourers here cannot be trusted, and I think that's where this came from, and I've only just had the time to inspect this memory.

But then again, isn't that weird? If we can't trust them, why're we entrusting such important tasks to them? Its quite a peculiar observation that while we don't see ourselves toiling, sweating and struggling without any sense of appreciation, some of us would immediately put ourselves at the frontline of a orientation event that admittedly feels a lot less important than this. And this makes me wonder, what do we really stand for today where what we do is concerned?

We live in two different worlds, two sides on the same coin.

We are two inherently different people. The difference is that there are more people whom you can relate with, while I venture into the unknown alone.

Love is something so much easier reciprocated and felt by most, but is often difficult for people like me. 
Can you feel the void within you? Can you feel the pain and sadness that nobody seems to understand about? Do you feel lonely that you're all alone, and empty that you do not have anyone who mutually wants to be with you? Can you feel the void taking over you?

I felt it all, and I have never stopped feeling any of it.

Hold on to the void for a while. See what it can do for you. You'll soon find that it can get real heavy.

Sunday dinner with Haozhe!

Don't worry about your absence @varun_shaji I accounted for that one!

Boy, was I magnificent with this one.

I'll be honest. You guys have been my best friends in Electrical Engineering (and also the first friends I've worked very closely with in Electrical Engineering since Year 2) and despite our mistakes, setbacks and difficulties, we'd always be there to support each other. We're walking our own paths at the moment, but we still got each other's backs. I know we'll walk our own paths in future, but I know that we'll look out for each other whenever we need it, wherever we need it. I know my status as the wildcard, the weird antics, jokes and eccentricity can be quite unbearable by many, but you know, it's a Kendrik thing. To many more dinners like these, where we talk about things inside and outside the classroom!

Me when I'm not smiling because a photo is being taken: has the photo been taken? Why is the sun so bright 😣 what am I doing here now? Did I just clear a 5km run? And how...? Park run at 7am is a special kind of pain.

Anyway, happy birthday Marcus and looks like you still got it in you! And good luck to those competing! I don't have Wei Yi's Instagram, so... cr: @micedogduck

Setback.

It took what effectively was a miracle and a breaking point for me to make a different decision. With these decisions however, comes different challenges. Challenges stronger than I thought, challenges more daunting than I have ever thought, and I know virtually nothing about them.

All I know is that I must become someone else, something else. All I know is that I must become something more, and my setbacks should not shape my trajectory.

Fullerton Bay, Singapore.

Two sides. The great contrast. Outside the exterior of a man who makes decisions in an instant out of necessity, is someone who carries the biggest doubts within.

Can he do better? What did it cost? Was there a way to avoid these losses?  Could there have been a different strategy?

No time to think sometimes. You do it first and give your apologies later. Some do it the other way around. Either way, there are two sides to this.

There are usually at least two sides to everything. That one can wield his doubts and darkness and use it to help himself as I have. That one can carry his losses in his stride, move forward and use these losses and the lessons learnt within to make a different decision.

"Aim for the moon. If you miss, you may hit a star"
- W. Clement Stone.

The first time I saw the night sky in Malaysia, I could actually see the stars.

Were we lighting lanterns? Hm. I don't remember. My memory has been a little scrambled ever since BMT. It's a long story there. It's also another story for another day.

And then there's the difference between here and the place I was in. I wonder, in the pursuit for a better future, to be recognized for something, did we neglect the stars that shone around the moon, or was it always that there was never the stars to look at to begin with? Or that if we knew that each star was a sun in itself, would we even aim for it in the first place?
Can't wait to go overseas by myself again.
The view from the corridor of my flat last night. I have not seen this view for a very long while.

It'll be a long haul.

Can't wait for the year to end.

Well. We cleared it.

Huh. I don't have Donovan's IG so I guess this'll have to do.

Didn't win but I guess we did much better than we could have despite the differences in skillsets.

Oh well.

At least I can now use that software I developed for my own uses.

Toa Payoh Lorong 5, Singapore.

You know, I've always wondered; quite a number of us always talk about the light at the end of the tunnel whenever the going gets hard.

I get that it's a metaphor, but I also always wondered, then what? What should I see after struggling and getting out of it?

Then again, for someone who has always preferred to think far and usually keeps an emotional distance (though I'm working on this), I think that light is nothing but a temporary reprieve.

What makes this any more correct than the things I use often and cannot find a way to disprove, then?

We were both like: "we're so screwed" because we both had like what, 5 different projects and 3-4 exams coming and we had to balance EE2028, ES1531, Innoventure (separate teams, but I pretty much did the Innoventure software alone and I hope I hit the mark), your iDP project and me, CS2040C (which is starting to get monstrously difficult) at the same time.

I'm glad we didn't give up though. Even if the blue LED spontaneously failed on us (seriously man not cool LPC1769, you worked fine before the assessment man) and I had to overcome a rejection with virtually a sleepless 2-3 weeks and an endless flurry of assignments and projects from everywhere and everyone, I think we managed to come out pretty well and I think we should be proud of it.

Screw that missing teammate you have, though 🤣

Marina Bay Sands, Singapore.

You can lift the heaviest weights, be the fastest man in the world, withstand even the most dangerous conditions without breaking, always score the highest for any examination or break even the toughest materials known to man, but the one with an eye for vision is the most powerful one of them all. 
One who has vision will never be too far behind in the other traits because the definition of vision warrants the accounting of eventualites that by sheer statistical probability, will invariably call for the potential use of something arbitrary, even if everything leads to a gamble or when correctness becomes subjective. He or she, with a clear view of the big picture in the future and in the now and past, the information and know-how to determine what happens next to the best of his or her ability, should know how to adapt to the situation whenever required no matter how dire.

He who has vision has a goal and he or she will do what he or she deems necessary in order to reach it.
